FedHPL: Efficient Heterogeneous Federated Learning with Prompt Tuning and Logit Distillation

Yuting Ma University of Science and Technology of China Lechao Cheng Yaxiong Wang Hefei University of Technology Zhun Zhong University of Nottingham Xiaohua Xu Meng Wang Hefei University of Technology
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a popular privacy-preserving paradigm that enables distributed clients to collaboratively train models with a central server while keeping raw data locally. In practice, distinct model architectures, varying data distributions, and limited resources across local clients inevitably cause model performance degradation and a slowdown in convergence speed. However, existing FL methods can only solve some of the above heterogeneous challenges and have obvious performance limitations. Notably, a unified framework has not yet been explored to overcome these challenges. Accordingly, we propose FedHPL, a parameter-efficient unified Federated learning framework for Heterogeneous settings based on Prompt tuning and Logit distillation. Specifically, we employ a local prompt tuning scheme that leverages a few learnable visual prompts to efficiently fine-tune the frozen pre-trained foundation model for downstream tasks, thereby accelerating training and improving model performance under limited local resources and data heterogeneity. Moreover, we design a global logit distillation scheme to handle the model heterogeneity and guide the local training. In detail, we leverage logits to implicitly capture local knowledge and design a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism to generate global client-specific logits. We provide a theoretical guarantee on the generalization error bound for FedHPL. The experiments on various benchmark datasets under diverse settings of models and data demonstrate that our framework outperforms state-of-the-art FL approaches, with less computation overhead and training rounds.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [38] is a privacy-preserving machine learning paradigm that enables decentralized parties to collaboratively train models in a distributed manner. This is achieved by sharing local model updates without exposing the underlying private data to the central server. Although FL has gained significant traction in homogeneous settings, it encounters challenges [31, 49, 50, 56] in heterogeneous settings over real-world clients. Data heterogeneity is a major challenge in FL, primarily caused by the imbalanced data distribution among clients. Most previous works [17, 25, 30, 32] have focused on addressing this challenge by optimizing the loss objective and aggregation process to reduce the discrepancy between the global distribution and clients’ distributions. However, these algorithms usually converge slowly and require more computing resources because they need to train the entire model from scratch.

A feasible mechanism [12, 16, 55] to speed up training and reduce trainable parameters over limited local resources is to select a pre-trained foundation model as the backbone of the local model and fine-tune it with visual prompt tuning (VPT) [24]. Specifically, clients freeze the large pre-trained backbone and only need to employ a few learnable task-specific prompts and a simple classification head for fine-tuning, which accelerates the convergence speed and reduces the computational burden with fewer trainable parameters. However, these studies only consider homogeneous clients and cannot generalize algorithms to clients with distinct local resources and different pre-trained models.

Recently, personalized federated learning (pFL) [10, 15, 36, 47], which considers the varying edge resource, has attracted research interests. In pFL, clients adopt personalized models for local training to maximize the utilization of local resources and adapt to local data distributions. In particular, if clients select different model structures, it constitutes another challenge in FL: model heterogeneity. The varying structures and embedding dimensions in model heterogeneity, leading to difficulties of global parameter aggregation in FL. To handle the problem, existing efforts generally fall into two categories: 1) exploiting knowledge distillation [9, 13, 28] to implicitly capture and transfer local distributions among clients instead of model updates; 2) aligning model architectures (e.g. adding projection layer or additional model structure) [48, 57, 59, 60] for model parameter aggregation. However, the above methods usually need more public resources and only consider model heterogeneity of small models, causing limited representation ability and performance improvement. But directly applying the large foundation models usually requires more computing resources and training rounds. Hence, we raise a question: How to implement federated learning in the setting of model heterogeneity and data heterogeneity among clients, while utilizing large foundation models in limited local resources and training rounds to improve the local model performance?

To answer this question, we propose a parameter-efficient unified FL framework named FedHPL in various settings of model architecture and data distribution as shown in Figure 1. Then we introduce our framework from two perspectives: local prompt tuning and global logit distillation. From the local perspective, we leverage the large pre-trained foundation model as the backbone of the local model and use its strong representations to alleviate performance degradation and adapt data heterogeneity. Moreover, we freeze the backbone and use a few learnable task-specific prompts along with a linear layer to fine-tune the local model over the limited local resources, further reducing the computing overhead and accelerating training speed. From the global perspective, we employ logit distillation [6], which solely depends on the number of labels, to handle model heterogeneity in FL. Specifically: 1) Clients only upload correctly predicted logits which implicitly represent local empirical knowledge distribution. 2) For generating global per-class logit for each client on the server side, we design a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism based on the proportion of latent dimensions among local models. 3) The global client-specific logits can transfer knowledge and guide local training. Furthermore, clients can average the uploading logits by class to reduce the communication overhead. Then, we provide a generalization error bound for FedHPL from prompt tuning and logit distillation, further demonstrating the impact of components in FedHPL on model performance, and accordingly investigate these components with experiments.

Contributions. In conclusion, our main contributions are: 1) We propose a novel parameter-efficient unified FL framework named FedHPL to address the challenge of model heterogeneity and data heterogeneity with limited local resources. We leverage local prompt tuning with pre-trained backbones and design a global logit distillation scheme with a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism. 2) We present a theoretical guarantee on the generalization error bound to show the influence of each component in FedHPL. 3) Experiments on three benchmark datasets in various settings show that FedHPL outperforms SOTA methods, with fewer trainable parameters and communication rounds.

2 Related work

Federated learning. FedAVG [38] is a distributed machine learning paradigm in which edge devices train models locally and upload model updates to a central server for parameter aggregation in collaborative learning. However, in real-world scenarios, data and models are usually heterogeneous, leading to challenges such as performance degradation. Some approaches [1, 25, 30, 32] add penalty terms to the loss function or align representations to address heterogeneous challenges, but they require that all clients and the central server share the same model structure. Alternatively, other studies [3, 36, 41] address the model heterogeneity challenge by designing customized models on the client side, known as pFL. However, it requires more convergence epochs to adapt simple model heterogeneity and often results in limited performance improvement. In contrast to them, our method selects appropriate pre-trained models as the backbone of local models and fine-tunes them with local prompt tuning and global logit distillation instead of designing customized models and aggregating model parameters in pFL, further handling both model heterogeneity and data heterogeneity.

Visual prompt tuning in federated learning. With the advancement of available public pre-trained foundation models [14, 19, 20, 43], VPT [24] and its variants [52, 58] have gained increasing popularity in federated learning. VPT exploits a large pre-trained model, a few task-specific learnable prompts, and a linear head for adapting downstream tasks. Recently, studies [16, 29, 55] have applied VPT to alleviate the model degradation due to data heterogeneity and reduce training time. For instance, pFedPG [55] trains personalized visual prompts on local devices with frozen pre-trained backbones and observes the local optimization direction to generate client-specific visual prompts through a prompt generator under data heterogeneity. However, these methods do not address the challenge of model heterogeneity, nor do they provide a theoretical bound for efficient fine-tuning in FL. This is a critical aspect where our work markedly differs from these approaches.

Knowledge distillation in federated learning. Knowledge distillation (KD) [22, 51] involves transferring knowledge from a larger pre-trained “teacher” model to a smaller “student” model, where the student learns to emulate the teacher’s behavior by producing similar outputs on a shared dataset. This technique leverages knowledge (e.g. feature embeddings or logits) transfer across clients rather than model parameter aggregation, making it a viable FL approach [7, 13, 28, 33, 50, 60] over model heterogeneity. Traditional methods (e.g. FedHKT [13], FedMD [28], and FedDF [33]) need to exploit public data to guide knowledge transfer between a central server and local clients. Recently, a data-free manner in knowledge distillation [6, 50, 60] has emerged in FL. For example, FedGen [60] introduces a lightweight global generator over model heterogeneity among clients and produces synthetic data to capture the global distribution, thereby eliminating the need for public datasets. The above methods tend to introduce shared datasets or additional model architecture to adapt to model heterogeneity, whereas we only select qualified logits without public data or extra models to facilitate knowledge transfer over model heterogeneity.

3.2 Local prompt tuning

Before performing classification tasks, each client downloads the appropriate pre-trained parameters of the foundation model from the server to Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} and keeps the backbone parameters frozen throughout the entire training phase. Then, each client injects a small number of learnable continuous visual parameters, denoted as prompts 𝖯ksubscript𝖯𝑘\mathsf{P}_{k}, into the input space of the backbone (typically using Transformer structures). These prompts can encode client-specific data distribution and guide the local training with the frozen backbone to adapt downstream tasks. After local prompt tuning based on VPT [24], the head output (i.e. logit) can implicitly capture local distribution knowledge.

Specifically, an image xkisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖x_{k}^{i} is divided into M𝑀M patches and embedded into a dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k}-dimensional latent space with position encoding, then gets Eki=LE,k​(xki),Eki∈ℝM×dkformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑖subscript𝐿𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑖superscriptℝ𝑀subscript𝑑𝑘E_{k}^{i}=L_{E,k}(x_{k}^{i}),E_{k}^{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times d_{k}}. As only 𝖯ksubscript𝖯𝑘\mathsf{P}_{k} and Hksubscript𝐻𝑘H_{k} need to be updated, clients reduce training burdens. Meanwhile, the well-trained backbone helps clients generate strong feature embeddings over limited data samples and data heterogeneity, thereby mitigating performance degradation and shortening the training time.

3.3 Global logit distillation

Since clients have different latent dimensions in model heterogeneity, traditional parameter aggregation on model updates or prompts is not suitable for collaborative learning. To solve this problem, we exploit knowledge distillation based on logits, which only related to the number of classes, and propose a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism based on qualified logits. We now describe the global logit distillation from client uploading, server aggregation, and logit distillation.

Client uploading. Client k𝑘k transfers the correctly predicted logits with corresponding labels as the local knowledge p→k:={pki,yki}i=1|𝒟~k|assignsubscript→𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝑖1subscript~𝒟𝑘\vec{p}_{k}:=\{p_{k}^{i},y_{k}^{i}\}_{i=1}^{|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{k}|} to the central server S𝑆S after local training, where |𝒟~k|subscript~𝒟𝑘|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{k}| is the number of correct logits. For those logits that are misclassified, i.e. yki≠argmaxc∈[0,nc−1][pki]cy_{k}^{i}\neq arg\max_{c\in[0,n_{c}-1]}[p_{k}^{i}]_{c}, we consider them as untrustworthy and do not upload them.

Server aggregation. After collecting all local logits from clients, the server generates the global logits with a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism. Generally, if a local model predicts more accurately in a certain label c𝑐c, then the corresponding uploading count of correct logits in this class |𝒟~k,c|subscript~𝒟𝑘𝑐|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{k,c}| will relatively increases, thus performing a higher influence on this class of global aggregation [44]. Therefore, we do not need to specially design a weight for the quantity and quality of uploading logits in the global aggregation. However, it is necessary to focus on the impact of the model heterogeneity on global aggregation. Inspired by [13, 26], we consider that models, that have similar architectures (e.g. latent dimensions), tend to learn comparable feature representations, and consequently capture similar knowledge distribution within logits for the same label. Accordingly, we intend to design the weight coefficient of model heterogeneity for the global logit aggregation from the latent dimension. Formally, given the latent embedding dimension djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j} of the model in client j𝑗j, the weight βk,jsubscript𝛽𝑘𝑗\beta_{k,j}, which determines the contribution of any client j𝑗j to the global client-specific logits in client k𝑘k, is denoted as:

βk,j=min⁡(dk/dj,dj/dk),∀j∈{1,⋯,K}.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛽𝑘𝑗subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝑑𝑘for-all𝑗1⋯𝐾\beta_{k,j}=\min({d_{k}}/{d_{j}},{d_{j}}/{d_{k}}),\forall j\in\{1,\cdots,K\}. (7)

A higher βk,jsubscript𝛽𝑘𝑗\beta_{k,j} implies the closer structures of two models, thereby leading to a more efficient aggregation. Then, S𝑆S generates the global per-class logit for client k𝑘k with the weight coefficient:

p~k,c=∑j=1Kβk,j​∑∀(pji,yji)∈p→j,yji=cpji1+∑j=1Kβk,j​|𝒟j,c|=∑j=1Kβ~k,j​∑i=1|𝒟~j,c|pj,ci,subscript~𝑝𝑘𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘𝑗subscriptformulae-sequencefor-allsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑖subscript→𝑝𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑖𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘𝑗subscript𝒟𝑗𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript~𝒟𝑗𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑐𝑖\tilde{p}_{k,c}=\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{K}\beta_{k,j}\sum_{\forall(p_{j}^{i},y_{j}^{i})\in\vec{p}_{j},y_{j}^{i}=c}p_{j}^{i}}{1+\sum_{j=1}^{K}\beta_{k,j}|{\mathcal{D}}_{j,c}|}=\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}_{j,c}|}p_{j,c}^{i}, (8)

where β~k,j=βk,j/(1+∑j=1Kβk,j​|𝒟j,c|)subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗subscript𝛽𝑘𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘𝑗subscript𝒟𝑗𝑐\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}=\beta_{k,j}/({1+\sum_{j=1}^{K}\beta_{k,j}|{\mathcal{D}}_{j,c}|}) is a constant and |𝒟j,c|subscript𝒟𝑗𝑐|\mathcal{D}_{j,c}| represents the number of samples (pj,cisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑐𝑖p_{j,c}^{i}) of client j𝑗j in class c𝑐c. We add one to the denominator to avoid the extreme case where all |𝒟j,c|subscript𝒟𝑗𝑐|{\mathcal{D}}_{j,c}| equals 00. Moreover, the global per-class logit p~k,csubscript~𝑝𝑘𝑐\tilde{p}_{k,c} mixes the local distribution of the certain class c𝑐c among clients rather than aggregating parameters trained on all labels, further alleviating the data heterogeneity caused by imbalanced class distribution. Particularly, the weighted aggregation mechanism is also suitable in homogeneous settings.

Logit distillation.

The global client-specific logits fuse the local knowledge of clients for each class and thus guide the local training without uploading private data. The local optimization for client k𝑘k is based on global logits under corresponding label c𝑐c (i.e. ykisuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖y_{k}^{i}) and the distillation loss:

ℓk​d=KL(e​x​p​(p~k,c/𝒯)∑c′=1nce​x​p​([p~k,c]c′/𝒯)||e​x​p​(pki/𝒯)∑c′=1nce​x​p​([pki]c′/𝒯)),\ell^{kd}={KL}(\frac{exp(\tilde{p}_{k,c}/\mathcal{T})}{{\textstyle\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{n_{c}}}exp([\tilde{p}_{k,c}]_{c^{\prime}}/\mathcal{T})}\left|\right|\frac{exp(p_{k}^{i}/\mathcal{T})}{{\textstyle\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{n_{c}}}exp([p_{k}^{i}]_{c^{\prime}}/\mathcal{T})}), (9)

where 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is a temperature coefficient in KD and K​L𝐾𝐿{KL} is the Kullback-Leibler divergence. Furthermore, clients can average local correctly predicted logits by category and only upload the per-class logits {p¯k,c}c=1ncsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript¯𝑝𝑘𝑐𝑐1subscript𝑛𝑐\{\bar{p}_{k,c}\}_{c=1}^{n_{c}} with the count of logits |𝒟~k,c|subscript~𝒟𝑘𝑐|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{k,c}| for each label c𝑐c to reduce the communication cost, where

p¯j,c=1|𝒟~j,c|​∑∀(pji,yji)∈p→j,yji=cpji.subscript¯𝑝𝑗𝑐1subscript~𝒟𝑗𝑐subscriptformulae-sequencefor-allsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑖subscript→𝑝𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑖𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑖\bar{p}_{j,c}=\frac{1}{|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{j,c}|}\textstyle\sum_{\forall(p_{j}^{i},y_{j}^{i})\in\vec{p}_{j},y_{j}^{i}=c}p_{j}^{i}. (10)

Theoretically speaking, p¯j,csubscript¯𝑝𝑗𝑐\bar{p}_{j,c} and pj,csubscript𝑝𝑗𝑐p_{j,c} are equivalent in global aggregation which we shown in Eq. (36) in Appendix. In summary, the training detail of FedHPL is shown in Algorithm 1.

3.4 Generalization error bound

Here, we investigate the bound of generalization error 𝐑𝔻T​(hk)subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{k}) in FedHPL for each model hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} of client k𝑘k over the test dataset 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} with its distribution 𝔻Tsubscript𝔻𝑇\mathbb{D}_{T} in arbitrary model and data settings. With an input space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and label space 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}, a hypothesis h:𝒳→𝒴:ℎ→𝒳𝒴h:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y} is the local model and ℋℋ\mathcal{H} is a hypotheses space on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. Suppose the local true and local empirical distribution for client k𝑘k over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y} as 𝔻ksubscript𝔻𝑘\mathbb{D}_{k} and 𝔻^ksubscript^𝔻𝑘\hat{\mathbb{D}}_{k}. Then we connect the error bound with the local training of client k𝑘k over the private dataset 𝒟k=(Xk,Yk)subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}=(X_{k},Y_{k}) with |𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘|\mathcal{D}_{k}| samples. The local training error is from the local prompt tuning error based on the cross-entropy loss and the logit distillation error between the weighted global logits and local logits. Accordingly, we define the local prompt tuning error as 𝐑𝔻^kc​e​(hk)superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript^𝔻𝑘𝑐𝑒subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\hat{\mathbb{D}}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k}) and the difference between the initial model h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} with the frozen pre-trained parameters and the fine-tuned model hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} as kl(hk||h0)kl(h_{k}||h_{0}). With the distillation loss (restricted by the bound Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k}), consisting of cross-entropy loss ℓc​e​(⋅,⋅)superscriptℓ𝑐𝑒⋅⋅\ell^{ce}(\cdot,\cdot) and information entropy I​(⋅)𝐼⋅I(\cdot), we present the multi-class generalization error bound for hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} over 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} in Theorem 1 and the proofs can deferred to Appendix A.

Theorem 1.

Suppose that K clients in FedHPL, let d𝒞h​(⋅,⋅)subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎ⋅⋅d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}(\cdot,\cdot) represents the distribution discrepancy between two data distributions. Given any data distribution 𝔻ksubscript𝔻𝑘\mathbb{D}_{k} and 𝔻^ksubscript^𝔻𝑘\hat{\mathbb{D}}_{k} over client k𝑘k and the local model hk∈ℋsubscriptℎ𝑘ℋh_{k}\in\mathcal{H} which fine-tuned from h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} (the distribution is πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k}). Taking any t>0𝑡0t>0 and λk=−log⁡πksubscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘\lambda_{k}=-\log\pi_{k}, the generalization error bound for hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} over 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} holds with the probability of at least 1−ϵ1italic-ϵ1-\epsilon:

𝐑𝔻T​(hk)≤𝐑𝔻^kc​e​(hk)+kl(hk||h0)+ln4​|𝒟k|−lnϵ2​|𝒟k|+λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h0)+d𝒞h​((𝔻k)X,(𝔻T)X)\displaystyle\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{k})\leq\mathbf{R}_{\hat{\mathbb{D}}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k})+\sqrt{\frac{kl(h_{k}||h_{0})+\ln\sqrt{4|{\mathcal{D}}_{k}|}-\ln\epsilon}{2|{\mathcal{D}}_{k}|}}+\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0})+d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}((\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X},(\mathbb{D}_{T})_{X})
+ℓc​e​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj)),ϕ𝒯​(hk​(Xk)))−I​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj)))+λk−log⁡ϵt​|𝒟k|+t​Ck28,superscriptℓ𝑐𝑒subscriptitalic-ϕ𝒯superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝒯subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘𝐼subscriptitalic-ϕ𝒯superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗subscript𝜆𝑘italic-ϵ𝑡subscript𝒟𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑘28\displaystyle+\ell^{ce}(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j})),\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(X_{k})))-I(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j})))+\frac{\lambda_{k}-\log\epsilon}{t|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}+\frac{tC_{k}^{2}}{8},

where ϕ𝒯subscriptitalic-ϕ𝒯\phi_{\mathcal{T}} is the softmax function with a temperature factor 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} and 𝒞h=h​Δ​ℋsubscript𝒞ℎℎΔℋ\mathcal{C}_{h}=h\Delta\mathcal{H}. λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h0)=𝐑𝔻k​(h0)+𝐑𝔻T​(h0)subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘subscriptℎ0subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0})=\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h_{0})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0}) measures the adaptation error of h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}.

Discussion. Based on this, we deduce the following: (1) If the initial model h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} (with frozen pre-trained parameters of Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} and initial 𝖯ksubscript𝖯𝑘\mathsf{P}_{k} and Hksubscript𝐻𝑘H_{k}) has a small error λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h0)subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0}), it is beneficial for improving generalization ability and model performance. (2) More samples |𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘|\mathcal{D}_{k}| can reduce generalization error and enhance the model utility. (3) A local distribution that is more similar to the global distribution, along with more precise global logits can reduce the error and promote local training, as analyzed in the Remark 3 of Appendix. (4) A higher distillation loss bound Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} and local tuning error 𝐑𝔻^kc​e​(hk)superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript^𝔻𝑘𝑐𝑒subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k}) undermine the generalization ability and model effectiveness. We can exploit the weight coefficient β~k,jsubscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗\tilde{\beta}_{k,j} and study the global knowledge to reduce them which we later show in Figure 3. (5) Obviously, less distribution discrepancy d𝒞hsubscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎd_{\mathcal{C}_{h}} can reduce the estimation error on 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}.

4 Experiments

4.1 Experimental settings

Datasets and models. We evaluate our method on CIFAR10, CIFAR100, and SVHN datasets under four settings shown in Figure 1. For IID data homogeneity setting, we randomly shuffle and partition data samples into clients, while we employ Dirichlet distribution Dir(α𝛼\alpha) with random α𝛼\alpha to perform Dir and Non-IID data heterogeneity settings, where the former has overlapping samples and the latter does not. For the model setting, we employ ViT-B/16 [14] in the homogeneous model experiments while using different ViT [14] or ResNet [21] as client backbones in the heterogeneous model experiments. These foundation models are both pre-trained on ImageNet1k [11]. The classification head is a linear fully connected layer. For more details, see Appendix B.2. Furthermore, we resize image pixels to 224 ×\times 224 for aligning the experiment setting of pre-trained backbones.

Implementation details. We train models by using the SGD optimizer with a learning rate of 0.01, a weight decay rate of 1e-4, and a momentum of 0.9. We perform 10 global rounds in CIFAR10 and 15 rounds in CIFAR100 and SVHN over 5 clients, while the local epoch is 1. The default style is VPT-deep with n=3𝑛3n=3 prompts for each backbone layer, and we fix 𝒯=4.5𝒯4.5\mathcal{T}=4.5 and γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1. For fair comparison, we run 100 global rounds on all baselines under the same model and data settings.

Baselines. We compare FedHPL against advanced FL approaches over two model settings with various data settings. For the homogeneous model setting, we compare our framework with loss-based FL (FedAVG [38], FedProx [32], SCAFFOLD [25]), pFL (FedBABU [40], FedRep [10]), and VPT-based FL (pFedPT [29], pFedPG [55]). For the heterogeneous model setting, we compare with model-based FL (FedGen [60], FedGH [57]), prototype-based FL (FedProto [48], FedTGP [59]), and distillation-based FL (FedMD [28], FedHE [6]). More details are in Appendix B.4.

4.2 Performance comparison with SOTA approaches

FedHPL achieves excellent results in model homogeneity. We compare FedHPL with existing FL approaches in the homogeneous model setting and the results are shown in Table 1. It can be seen that FedHPL outperforms other algorithms across all settings with the least trainable parameters. For example, the average test accuracy is basically 30% and 45% higher than other methods (except pFedPG) on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100. We attribute such consistent outperformance to the strong representations of pre-trained backbones and effective guidance of global knowledge.

FedHPL can adapt model heterogeneity. We next compare the model performance with other FL methods in the heterogeneous model setting. Notably, due to the prevalent implementation of CNN in these approaches, FedHPL adopts a mechanism of padding learnable height and width pixels as prompts to the image space and performs local training over CNN backbones instead of Transformer for fair comparison. Table 2 illustrates the comparison results and it can be seen that FedHPL achieves the highest accuracy across CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets. For instance, in the Dir data setting, the test accuracy in FedHPL is 35.99% and 42.85% higher than the lowest accuracy of baselines on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, while in the IID data setting, it is 44.21% and 52.70% higher, respectively. It proves the feasibility and effectiveness of FedHPL in model heterogeneity.

Select ViT as the pre-trained backbone. We also notice that FedHPL with ViT achieves competitive performance over most situations while the performance with CNN is not ideal on SVHN dataset. For example, the test accuracy improves 21.76%, 27.47%, and 30.24% in FedHPL from ResNet to ViT on SVHN dataset. Refer to [24], the advantage of VPT can be better fulfilled with Transformers and diminish with smaller CNN. We think λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h0)subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0}) in ViT is smaller than CNN and learnable parameters can be better trained over ViT backbones. Therefore, it is preferred to choose ViT structures as pre-trained backbones. See Appendix C.3 for more details about model performance.

4.3 Ablation study and analysis

According to Theorem 1, the model performance is affected by many factors. To investigate their influence, we conduct the ablation study over the CIFAR10 dataset with ViT backbones.

Effect of prompt length and insertion position. Figure 3(a) exhibits performance comparison results with VPT-shallow and VPT-deep over the varying prompt length for a backbone layer (i.e. n𝑛n) in the Dir data and heterogeneous model setting. With tolerant trainable parameters (shown in Table 6), VPT-deep has better performance (especially for the lowest client accuracy with a maximum performance improvement of 6.6%) by promoting the generalization ability of h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} with efficient 𝖯ksubscript𝖯𝑘\mathsf{P}_{k} and reducing λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h0)subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0}). Thus, we use VPT-deep as the default insertion style in FedHPL.

Sensitivity to the number of involved training samples. Figure 3(b) shows the exploration results among clients over the IID and homogeneous model setting. It provides compelling evidence that a higher number percentage of data involved in local training (i.e. more samples |𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘|\mathcal{D}_{k}|) can improve the model performance, indicating a reduction in the error bound 𝐑𝔻T​(hk)subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{k}). Meanwhile, the error can further decrease by collaborative learning to strengthen the local model hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} and further alleviate the negative impact caused by insufficient local samples. Furthermore, Table 3(left) shows that imbalanced data (the smaller α𝛼\alpha, the higher data heterogeneity) only cause a slight performance degradation and variance, revealing the capacity of FedHPL to handle data heterogeneity.

Necessity of weighted aggregation. In addition to local prompt tuning, global logit distillation also influences the model utility. We selectively remove specific components from FedHPL (i.e. weighted aggregation →→\to average aggregation, uploading correct logits →→\to uploading all logits) in the heterogeneous model setting to investigate their contributions. From Figure 3(c), we can observe that the average aggregation mechanism causes an accuracy decline, highlighting the effectiveness of the weighted aggregation mechanism. The weight factor can increase the logit proportion of similar models, further decreasing the distillation error. In addition, uploading all logits yields slightly lower accuracy than uploading correct predictions. We believe that incorrect predictions have a negative impact on global logits and detailed analyze at Remark 3. Interestingly, the performance of Local (i.e. only exploit local prompt tuning) is good enough. This also explains why uploading incorrect predictions only has a slight negative effect, as the number of incorrect predictions is small.

Exploiting homogeneous parameters. We next give insights on facilitating performance in FedHPL from the same latent dimension. Specifically, clients additionally upload prompts or head parameters, which the server then aggregates by the same dimension and transmits the aggregated knowledge to corresponding clients. Table 3(right) reports that aggregating prompts or head parameters with FedHPL can further improve the model performance in most cases. Additional global prompts and head parameters can help clients to learn more knowledge and decrease the distribution difference to reduce the error bound. Furthermore, FedHPL can save communication costs by uploading per-class average local logits while maintaining comparable performance, as we show in Appendix C.2.

Broader impact and limitation. FedHPL uploads logits instead of private data and provides a privacy-preserving paradigm in machine learning. Furthermore, the generalization ability to unseen datasets that have large domain shifts to clients has not been explored. We leave it for future work.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we propose a novel unified framework named FedHPL, designed to tackle heterogeneity issues in federated learning. To handle data heterogeneity and accelerate training, we leverage pre-trained foundation models and local prompt tuning over limited local resources to fine-tune local models. For collaborative training among heterogeneous models, we design a global logit distillation scheme with a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism. Furthermore, we derived a generalization error bound for FedHPL to show how prompt tuning and logit distillation affect the model performance. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of FedHPL across various settings compared with other baselines and validate our theoretical guarantee.

Appendix A Proofs of Theorem 1

A.1 Generalization error bound over local data distribution

In this subsection, we show how the generalization error 𝐑𝔻T​(hk)subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{k}) over the local model hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} of client k𝑘k in Theorem 1 is connected from the test dataset 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} to the local private dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. Then, we get an error bound over the local private dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}.

A.1.1 Preliminaries

We first introduce several definitions and existing lemmas.

Definition 1 (Risk).

Inspired by [45], given the input space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} with finite label space 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} more than two classes and a hypothesis (i.e. model) h∈ℋℎℋh\in\mathcal{H}. The generalization error (or risk) 𝐑𝔻subscript𝐑𝔻\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}: 𝒴𝒳→[0,1]→superscript𝒴𝒳01\mathcal{Y}^{\mathcal{X}}\to[0,1] is defined on the distribution 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}:

𝐑𝔻​(h)​=d​e​f​𝐏𝐫(X,Y)∼𝔻​(M​(h​(X))≠Y),subscript𝐑𝔻ℎ𝑑𝑒𝑓subscript𝐏𝐫similar-to𝑋𝑌𝔻𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑌\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)\overset{def}{=}\mathbf{Pr}_{\left(X,Y\right)\sim\mathbb{D}}\left(M(h(X))\neq Y\right), (11)

where M​(h​(X))𝑀ℎ𝑋M(h(X))=a​r​g​maxc∈Y⁡h​(X)c𝑎𝑟𝑔subscript𝑐𝑌ℎsubscript𝑋𝑐arg\max_{c\in Y}h(X)_{c}. According to [54], given the indicator function 𝟏​[⋅]1delimited-[]⋅\mathbf{1}[\cdot], we have:

𝐏𝐫(X,Y)∼𝔻​(M​(h​(X))≠Y)=𝔼(X,Y)∼𝔻​𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠Y].subscript𝐏𝐫similar-to𝑋𝑌𝔻𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑌subscript𝔼similar-to𝑋𝑌𝔻1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑌\mathbf{Pr}_{(X,Y)\sim\mathbb{D}}(M(h(X))\neq Y)=\mathbb{E}_{(X,Y)\sim\mathbb{D}}\mathbf{1}\left[M(h(X))\neq Y\right]. (12)
Definition 2 (h​Δ​ℋℎΔℋh\Delta\mathcal{H}-divergence [45]).

Given a class of hypothesis ℋ⊆𝒴𝒳ℋsuperscript𝒴𝒳\mathcal{H}\subseteq\mathcal{Y}^{\mathcal{X}}, for h∈ℋℎℋh\in\mathcal{H},

h​Δ​ℋ​=d​e​f​{x↦1−𝟏{h​(x)}​{h′​(x)}|h′∈ℋ},ℎΔℋ𝑑𝑒𝑓conditional-setmaps-to𝑥1subscript1ℎ𝑥superscriptℎ′𝑥superscriptℎ′ℋh\Delta\mathcal{H}\overset{def}{=}\{x\mapsto 1-\mathbf{1}_{\{h(x)\}}\{h^{\prime}(x)\}|h^{\prime}\in\mathcal{H}\}, (13)

which is a model-dependent extension of ℋ​Δ​ℋ​=d​e​f​{x↦1−𝟏{h​(x)}​{h′​(x)}|(h,h′)∈ℋ2}ℋΔℋ𝑑𝑒𝑓conditional-setmaps-to𝑥1subscript1ℎ𝑥superscriptℎ′𝑥ℎsuperscriptℎ′superscriptℋ2\mathcal{H}\Delta\mathcal{H}\overset{def}{=}\{x\mapsto 1-\mathbf{1}_{\{h(x)\}}\{h^{\prime}(x)\}|(h,h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{H}^{2}\}.

Definition 3 (Supremum inequality about 𝒞hsubscript𝒞ℎ\mathcal{C}_{h} [45]).

Given any distributions 𝔻1subscript𝔻1\mathbb{D}_{1} and 𝔻2subscript𝔻2\mathbb{D}_{2} over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}, for any choice of 𝒞h=h​Δ​ℋsubscript𝒞ℎℎΔℋ\mathcal{C}_{h}=h\Delta\mathcal{H},

ξ=|𝔼X1∼(𝔻1)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(X1))≠M​(h′​(X1))]−𝔼X2∼(𝔻2)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(X2))≠M​(h′​(X2))]|≤d𝒞h​((𝔻2)X,(𝔻1)X),𝜉subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑋1subscriptsubscript𝔻1𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎsubscript𝑋1𝑀superscriptℎ′subscript𝑋1subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑋2subscriptsubscript𝔻2𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎsubscript𝑋2𝑀superscriptℎ′subscript𝑋2subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎsubscriptsubscript𝔻2𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻1𝑋\begin{split}\xi&=\left|\mathbb{E}_{X_{1}\sim(\mathbb{D}_{1})_{X}}\mathbf{1}[M(h(X_{1}))\neq M(h^{\prime}(X_{1}))]-\mathbb{E}_{X_{2}\sim(\mathbb{D}_{2})_{X}}\mathbf{1}[M(h(X_{2}))\neq M(h^{\prime}(X_{2}))]\right|\\ &\leq d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}((\mathbb{D}_{2})_{X},(\mathbb{D}_{1})_{X}),\end{split} (14)

where 𝔻𝒳subscript𝔻𝒳\mathbb{D}_{\mathcal{X}} is the 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}-marginal of 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}. More details about 𝒞hsubscript𝒞ℎ\mathcal{C}_{h} can refer to the Theorem 5 in [45].

Lemma 1 (PAC-Bayesian Theorem [46]).

Let ℓℓ\ell be a [0,1]-bounded loss function, given the risk 𝐑𝔻​(h)subscript𝐑𝔻ℎ\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h) over the distribution 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}, the empirical risk 𝐑𝔻^​(h)subscript𝐑^𝔻ℎ\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h) trained with the loss function ℓℓ\ell over the empirical distribution 𝔻^^𝔻\mathbb{\hat{D}}, and h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} (e.g. the initial model with pre-trained parameters) be a probability distribution over ℋℋ\mathcal{H}. For ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1),

𝐑𝔻​(h)≤𝐑𝔻^​(h)+kl(h||h0)+ln4​m−lnϵ2​m,\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)\leq\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)+\sqrt{\frac{kl(h||h_{0})+\ln\sqrt{4m}-\ln\epsilon}{2m}}, (15)

where k​l𝑘𝑙kl is the KL-divergence and m𝑚m is the number of samples.

Proof.

For a probability distribution ℙℙ\mathbb{P} (i.e. h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}) over ℋℋ\mathcal{H} and δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, the above lemma is the loosen result of [37], which is given below:

𝐏𝐫(∀ℚ⊆ℋ:kl(𝐑𝔻^(ℚ)||𝐑𝔻(ℚ))≤kl(ℚ||ℙ)+ln4​m−lnδm)≥1−δ,\mathbf{Pr}(\forall\mathbb{Q}\subseteq\mathcal{H}:kl(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(\mathbb{Q})||\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(\mathbb{Q}))\leq\frac{kl(\mathbb{Q}||\mathbb{P})+\ln\sqrt{4m}-\ln\delta}{m})\geq 1-\delta,

by applying Pinsker’s inequality. Inspired by [34, 46], we replace ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} with hℎh. ∎

Lemma 2 (Adaptation of the triangle-inequality [4, 45]).

For any (h,h′)∈ℋ2ℎsuperscriptℎ′superscriptℋ2(h,h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{H}^{2}, we have the below inequalities by using the triangle inequality:

𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠Y]≤𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠M​(h′​(X))]+𝟏​[M​(h′​(X))≠Y],1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑌1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋𝑌\mathbf{1}[M(h(X))\neq Y]\leq\mathbf{1}[M(h(X))\neq M(h^{\prime}(X))]+\mathbf{1}[M(h^{\prime}(X))\neq Y], (16)
𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠M​(h′​(X))]≤𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠Y]+𝟏​[Y≠M​(h′​(X))].1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑌1delimited-[]𝑌𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋\mathbf{1}[M(h(X))\neq M(h^{\prime}(X))]\leq\mathbf{1}[M(h(X))\neq Y]+\mathbf{1}[Y\neq M(h^{\prime}(X))]. (17)

A.1.2 Bound with local data distribution

Based on the above definitions and lemmas, we have the generalization error over 𝔻Tsubscript𝔻𝑇\mathbb{D}_{T} bounded with the local data distribution 𝔻ksubscript𝔻𝑘\mathbb{D}_{k}.

Theorem 2.

With K clients and a server in FL, 𝔻^ksubscript^𝔻𝑘\mathbb{\hat{D}}_{k} is the empirical distribution of client k𝑘k from the private training dataset which has |𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘|\mathcal{D}_{k}| samples and 𝔻ksubscript𝔻𝑘\mathbb{D}_{k} is the true distribution of client k𝑘k. 𝔻Tsubscript𝔻𝑇\mathbb{D}_{T} is the data distribution from the test dataset and it is usually used to estimate the model performance. h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} is the initial model with a pre-trained backbone, trainable prompts, and a classification head. hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} is the fine-tuned model from h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} after training. Given any hk∈ℋsubscriptℎ𝑘ℋh_{k}\in\mathcal{H} for client k𝑘k and ∀δ∈(0,1)for-all𝛿01\forall\delta\in(0,1), with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, the generalization error bound over the test dataset is:

𝐑𝔻T​(hk)≤𝐑𝔻k​(hk)+λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h′)+d𝒞h​((𝔻k)X,(𝔻T)X),subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎsubscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑇𝑋\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{k})\leq\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{{D}}_{k}}(h_{k})+\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h^{\prime})+d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}((\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X},(\mathbb{D}_{T})_{X}),

where λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h′)=𝐑𝔻k​(h′)+𝐑𝔻T​(h′)subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘superscriptℎ′subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h^{\prime})=\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h^{\prime})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h^{\prime}) for any h′∈ℋsuperscriptℎ′ℋh^{\prime}\in\mathcal{H} and 𝒞h=h​Δ​ℋsubscript𝒞ℎℎΔℋ\mathcal{C}_{h}=h\Delta\mathcal{H}.

Proof.

Recall Eq. (16) in Lemma 2, for any h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}, we have the below inequality by monotonicity and linearity of expectation

+𝔼(X,Y)∼𝔻T​𝟏​[M​(h′​(X))≠Y].subscript𝔼similar-to𝑋𝑌subscript𝔻𝑇1delimited-[]𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋𝑌\displaystyle+\mathbb{E}_{(X,Y)\sim\mathbb{D}_{T}}\mathbf{1}[M(h^{\prime}(X))\neq Y].

Then, applying Definition 1 and Definition 3, we have:

𝐑𝔻T​(h)=𝔼(X,Y)∼𝔻T​𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠Y]≤𝔼X∼(𝔻T)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠M​(h′​(X))]+𝔼(X,Y)∼𝔻T​𝟏​[M​(h′​(X))≠Y]=𝔼X∼(𝔻T)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠M​(h′​(X))]+𝐑𝔻T​(h′)≤𝔼Xk∼(𝔻k)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(Xk))≠M​(h′​(Xk))]+𝐑𝔻T​(h′)+|𝔼X∼(𝔻T)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(X))≠M​(h′​(X))]−𝔼Xk∼(𝔻k)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(Xk))≠M​(h′​(Xk))]|=𝔼Xk∼(𝔻k)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(Xk))≠M​(h′​(Xk))]+𝐑𝔻T​(h′)+d𝒞h​((𝔻k)X,(𝔻T)X),subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇ℎsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑋𝑌subscript𝔻𝑇1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑌subscript𝔼similar-to𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑇𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋subscript𝔼similar-to𝑋𝑌subscript𝔻𝑇1delimited-[]𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋𝑌subscript𝔼similar-to𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑇𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑘subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎsubscript𝑋𝑘𝑀superscriptℎ′subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′subscript𝔼similar-to𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑇𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎ𝑋𝑀superscriptℎ′𝑋subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑘subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎsubscript𝑋𝑘𝑀superscriptℎ′subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑘subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎsubscript𝑋𝑘𝑀superscriptℎ′subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎsubscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑇𝑋\begin{split}\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h)&=\mathbb{E}_{(X,Y)\sim\mathbb{D}_{T}}\mathbf{1}[M(h(X))\neq M(h^{\prime}(X_{k}))]+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h^{\prime})+d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}((\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X},(\mathbb{D}_{T})_{X}),\end{split} (18)

where d𝒞h​[⋅,⋅]subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎ⋅⋅d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}[\cdot,\cdot] represents the distribution discrepancy between two distributions.

Similarly, recall Eq. (17) in Lemma 2, we have the below inequality with (Xk,Yk)∼𝔻ksimilar-tosubscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝔻𝑘(X_{k},Y_{k})\sim\mathbb{D}_{k}:

𝔼Xk∼(𝔻k)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(Xk))≠M​(h′​(Xk))]≤𝔼Xk∼(𝔻k)X​𝟏​[M​(h​(Xk))≠Yk]+𝔼Xk∼(𝔻k)X​𝟏​[Yk≠M​(h′​(Xk))]=𝐑𝔻k​(h)+𝐑𝔻k​(h′).subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑘subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎsubscript𝑋𝑘𝑀superscriptℎ′subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑘subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋1delimited-[]𝑀ℎsubscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑘subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋1delimited-[]subscript𝑌𝑘𝑀superscriptℎ′subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘ℎsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘superscriptℎ′\begin{split}\mathbb{E}_{X_{k}\sim(\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X}}\mathbf{1}[M(h(X_{k}))\neq M(h^{\prime}(X_{k}))]&\leq\mathbb{E}_{X_{k}\sim(\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X}}\mathbf{1}[M(h(X_{k}))\neq Y_{k}]\\ &+\mathbb{E}_{X_{k}\sim(\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X}}\mathbf{1}[Y_{k}\neq M(h^{\prime}(X_{k}))]\\ &=\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h)+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h^{\prime}).\\ \end{split} (19)

By combining Eq. (18) and Eq. (19), for any h∈ℋℎℋh\in\mathcal{H},

𝐑𝔻T​(h)≤𝐑𝔻k​(h)+𝐑𝔻k​(h′)+𝐑𝔻T​(h′)+d𝒞h​((𝔻k)X,(𝔻T)X).subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇ℎsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘ℎsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘superscriptℎ′subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎsubscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑇𝑋\begin{split}\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h)&\leq\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h)+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h^{\prime})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h^{\prime})+d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}((\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X},(\mathbb{D}_{T})_{X}).\end{split}

Moreover, hℎh in FedHPL is the local fine-tuned model hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}, so we have:

𝐑𝔻T​(hk)≤𝐑𝔻k​(hk)+𝐑𝔻k​(h′)+𝐑𝔻T​(h′)+d𝒞h​((𝔻k)X,(𝔻T)X).subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘superscriptℎ′subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎsubscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑇𝑋\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{k})\leq\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h_{k})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h^{\prime})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h^{\prime})+d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}((\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X},(\mathbb{D}_{T})_{X}). (20)

∎

Furthermore, because λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h′)subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇superscriptℎ′\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h^{\prime}) is suitable for any model h′∈ℋsuperscriptℎ′ℋh^{\prime}\in\mathcal{H}, Eq. (20) can further derived when using h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} to replace h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}:

𝐑𝔻T​(hk)≤𝐑𝔻k​(hk)+𝐑𝔻k​(h0)+𝐑𝔻T​(h0)+d𝒞h​((𝔻k)X,(𝔻T)X).subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘subscriptℎ0subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎsubscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑋subscriptsubscript𝔻𝑇𝑋\begin{split}\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{k})&\leq\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h_{k})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h_{0})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0})+d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}((\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X},(\mathbb{D}_{T})_{X}).\end{split} (21)
Remark 1.

hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} is fine-tuned from h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} by the local prompt tuning and global logit distillation with a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism. 𝐑𝔻k​(h0)+𝐑𝔻T​(h0)subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘subscriptℎ0subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h_{0})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0}) represents the model adaptation error of h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} after transferring it from the source domain (e.g. ImageNet) to the new domain (e.g. CIFAR10, CIFAR100, SVHN). We consider λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h0)subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0}) reflects the generalization ability of h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} (the initial model with pre-trained backbone and initial trainable parameters). The more robust the pre-trained backbone, the stronger the generalization ability in h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} will be and the corresponding error λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h0)subscript𝜆subscript𝔻𝑘subscript𝔻𝑇subscriptℎ0\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0}) will be reduced. Additionally, the trainable parameters (i.e. visual prompts and the classification head) also have an impact on model generalization on h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}. Moreover, the distribution discrepancy d𝒞h​(⋅,⋅)subscript𝑑subscript𝒞ℎ⋅⋅d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}(\cdot,\cdot) between two data distributions also influences the generalization error.

In FedHPL, 𝐑𝔻k​(hk)subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h_{k}) consists of the error 𝐑𝔻kc​e​(hk)superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑐𝑒subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k}) in local prompt tuning and distillation error 𝐑𝔻kk​d​(hk)superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑘𝑑subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{kd}(h_{k}) in global logit distillation with a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism. According to Lemma 1, we can simply use 𝐑𝔻^kc​e​(hk)+kl(hk||h0)+ln4​|𝒟k|−lnϵ2​|𝒟k|\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k})+\sqrt{\frac{kl(h_{k}||h_{0})+\ln\sqrt{4|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}-\ln\epsilon}{2|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}} to represent 𝐑𝔻kc​e​(hk)superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑐𝑒subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k}) because the true data distribution is hard to estimate and we usually use the empirical data to estimate. The trainable parameters can affect the error bound from the local training and kl(hk||h0)kl(h_{k}||h_{0}). According to [53], we use a cross-entropy loss function to train hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} in the stage of local prompt tuning instead of M​(hk​(Xk))=a​r​g​maxc∈Yk⁡hk​(Xk)c𝑀subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘𝑎𝑟𝑔subscript𝑐subscript𝑌𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑋𝑘𝑐M(h_{k}(X_{k}))=arg\max_{c\in Y_{k}}h_{k}(X_{k})_{c} since it is hard to optimize. However, the distillation error with a KD loss ℓk​dsuperscriptℓ𝑘𝑑\ell^{kd} is more complicated and related to logits. Furthermore, the KL loss is not mentioned in [53], so we decided to analyze it from another perspective.

A.2 Generalization error bound over global logit distillation

In this subsection, we apply a simple PAC-Bayes bound for estimating the effectiveness of global logit distillation with a weighted knowledge distillation mechanism in federated learning and observe its influence on the generalization error. Due to the fact that KL divergence does not necessarily satisfy the Lipschitz condition, traditional bound analysis cannot be suitable in our setting. Inspired by [2], this paper defines a generalized bound based on the loss function.

A.2.1 Preliminaries

Here, we show some definitions and lemmas before demonstrating our theorem.

Given a random variable U𝑈U and s∈ℝ𝑠ℝs\in\mathbb{R}, for any a>0𝑎0a>0,

𝐏𝐫​(U>s)=𝐏𝐫​(ea​U>ea​s)≤𝔼​(ea​U)ea​s,𝐏𝐫𝑈𝑠𝐏𝐫superscript𝑒𝑎𝑈superscript𝑒𝑎𝑠𝔼superscript𝑒𝑎𝑈superscript𝑒𝑎𝑠\begin{split}\mathbf{Pr}(U>s)&=\mathbf{Pr}(e^{aU}>e^{as})\\ &\leq\frac{\mathbb{E}(e^{aU})}{e^{as}},\end{split}

which is the exponential version of Markov inequality.

A.2.2 Bound with local risks

Before we prove the generalization error bound over logit distillation loss, we first derive the bound with risks over the local dataset and model. Here, we modify Lemma 3 for easier proving.

Corollary 1 (Hoeffding’s Inequality over Local Risks).

Given the empirical distribution 𝔻^^𝔻\mathbb{\hat{D}} from samples 𝒟=[(x1,y1),⋯,(xm,ym)]𝒟superscript𝑥1superscript𝑦1⋯superscript𝑥𝑚superscript𝑦𝑚\mathcal{D}=[(x^{1},y^{1}),\cdots,(x^{m},y^{m})] and true distribution 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}, for any t∈ℝ+𝑡superscriptℝt\in\mathbb{R}^{+},

𝔼𝒟​[et​m​(𝐑𝔻​(h)−𝐑𝔻^​(h))]≤em​C2​t28.subscript𝔼𝒟delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑡𝑚subscript𝐑𝔻ℎsubscript𝐑^𝔻ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑚superscript𝐶2superscript𝑡28\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}[e^{tm(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)-\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h))}]\leq e^{\frac{mC^{2}t^{2}}{8}}. (28)
Proof.

Combine Lemma 4 with Lemma 3, suppose ∀Ui∈[ai,bi]for-allsuperscript𝑈𝑖superscript𝑎𝑖superscript𝑏𝑖\forall U^{i}\in[a^{i},b^{i}], we have:

𝔼​[et​∑i=1m(Ui−𝔼​[Ui])]=∏i=1m𝔼​[et​(Ui−𝔼​[Ui])]≤∏i=1me(bi−ai)2​t28.𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscript𝑈𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑈𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑡superscript𝑈𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑈𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚superscript𝑒superscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑖superscript𝑎𝑖2superscript𝑡28\begin{split}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{t\sum_{i=1}^{m}(U^{i}-\mathbb{E}[U^{i}])}\right]&=\prod_{i=1}^{m}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{t(U^{i}-\mathbb{E}[U^{i}])}\right]\\ &\leq\prod_{i=1}^{m}e^{\frac{(b^{i}-a^{i})^{2}t^{2}}{8}}.\end{split}

Suppose ∀ai,bifor-allsuperscript𝑎𝑖superscript𝑏𝑖\forall a^{i},b^{i} satisfies bi−ai≤b−asuperscript𝑏𝑖superscript𝑎𝑖𝑏𝑎b^{i}-a^{i}\leq b-a, we get:

𝔼​[et​∑i=1m(Ui−𝔼​[Ui])]≤∏i=1me(bi−ai)2​t28=e∑i=1m(bi−ai)2​t28≤em​(b−a)2​t28.𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscript𝑈𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑈𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚superscript𝑒superscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑖superscript𝑎𝑖2superscript𝑡28superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑖superscript𝑎𝑖2superscript𝑡28superscript𝑒𝑚superscript𝑏𝑎2superscript𝑡28\begin{split}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{t\sum_{i=1}^{m}(U^{i}-\mathbb{E}[U^{i}])}\right]&\leq\prod_{i=1}^{m}e^{\frac{(b^{i}-a^{i})^{2}t^{2}}{8}}\\ &=e^{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{(b^{i}-a^{i})^{2}t^{2}}{8}}\\ &\leq e^{\frac{m(b-a)^{2}t^{2}}{8}}.\end{split}

With Ui=𝔼𝒟​[ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)]−ℓ​(h​(xi),yi),𝒟={(xi,yi)}i=1m∼𝔻^formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝔼𝒟delimited-[]ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖𝒟superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑚similar-to^𝔻U^{i}=\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}[\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})]-\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i}),\mathcal{D}=\{(x^{i},y^{i})\}_{i=1}^{m}\sim\mathbb{\hat{D}} and Definition 4, we derive that:

∑i=1m(Ui−𝔼​[Ui])superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscript𝑈𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑈𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{m}(U^{i}-\mathbb{E}[U^{i}]) =∑i=1m(𝔼𝒟​[ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)]−ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)−𝔼​[𝔼𝒟​[ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)]−ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)])absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝔼𝒟delimited-[]ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝒟delimited-[]ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{m}(\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}[\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})]-\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})-\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}[\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})]-\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})])
=∑i=1m(𝔼𝒟​[ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)]−ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)−𝔼𝒟​[ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)]+𝔼​[ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)])absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝔼𝒟delimited-[]ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝔼𝒟delimited-[]ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖𝔼delimited-[]ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{m}(\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}[\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})]-\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})-\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}[\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})]+\mathbb{E}[\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})])
=∑i=1m𝔼​[ℓ​(h​(xi),yi)]−∑i=1mℓ​(h​(xi),yi)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚𝔼delimited-[]ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathbb{E}[\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})]-\sum_{i=1}^{m}\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})
=m​[𝐑𝔻​(h)−𝐑𝔻^​(h)].absent𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝐑𝔻ℎsubscript𝐑^𝔻ℎ\displaystyle=m[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)-\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)].

According Definition 4, ℓ∈[0,C]ℓ0𝐶\ell\in[0,C], we consider b−a=C𝑏𝑎𝐶b-a=C. Apply the above equality to 𝔼​[et​∑i=1m(Ui−𝔼​[Ui])]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscript𝑈𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑈𝑖\mathbb{E}\left[e^{t\sum_{i=1}^{m}(U^{i}-\mathbb{E}[U^{i}])}\right] and consider the dataset 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}, the proof ends. ∎

Then, following Corollary 1 and Lemma 5, we have the below theorem to connect the generalization bound with the risks over the local dataset and model.

Theorem 3.

For any t∈ℝ+𝑡superscriptℝt\in\mathbb{R}^{+} and ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1),

𝐏𝐫​[∀ρ∈𝒫​(Θ),𝔼θ∼ρ​[𝐑𝔻​(h)]≤𝔼θ∼ρ​[𝐑𝔻^​(h)]+kl(ρ||π)−logϵt​m+t​C28]≥1−ϵ.\mathbf{Pr}\left[\forall\rho\in\mathcal{P}(\Theta),\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)]\leq\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)]+\frac{kl(\rho||\pi)-\log\epsilon}{tm}+\frac{tC^{2}}{8}\right]\geq 1-\epsilon. (29)
Remark 2.

The parameter θ𝜃\theta of hℎh is the full parameter, instead of the parameter of a classification head in the main text.

Proof.

According to [2], given the hypothesis hℎh (i.e. the fine-tuned model from h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}) with its parameter θ∈Θ𝜃Θ\theta\in\Theta. Considering the influence of the prior model h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} with its fixed distribution π𝜋\pi, we integrate it into Corollary 1 and exchange the integration and sample expectation by Fubini:

𝔼𝒟​𝔼θ∼π​[et​m​[𝐑𝔻​(h)−𝐑𝔻^​(h)]]≤em​C2​t28.subscript𝔼𝒟subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝜋delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑡𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝐑𝔻ℎsubscript𝐑^𝔻ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑚superscript𝐶2superscript𝑡28\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\pi}[e^{tm[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)-\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)]}]\leq e^{\frac{mC^{2}t^{2}}{8}}.

Thanks to Lemma 5, the above bound can measure from prior model distribution π𝜋\pi to any model distribution ρ𝜌\rho:

𝔼𝒟​[esupρ∼𝒫​(Θ){tm𝔼θ∼ρ[𝐑𝔻(h)−𝐑𝔻^(h)]−kl(ρ||π)}]≤em​t2​C28.\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}\left[e^{\underset{\rho\sim\mathcal{P}(\Theta)}{\sup}\{tm\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)-\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)]-kl(\rho||\pi)\}}\right]\leq e^{\frac{mt^{2}C^{2}}{8}}.

Then, divide both sides of the equation by em​t2​C28superscript𝑒𝑚superscript𝑡2superscript𝐶28e^{\frac{mt^{2}C^{2}}{8}}, it gets:

𝔼𝒟​[esupρ∼𝒫​(Θ){tm𝔼θ∼ρ[𝐑𝔻(h)−𝐑𝔻^(h)]−kl(ρ||π)}−m​t2​C28]≤1.\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}\left[e^{\underset{\rho\sim\mathcal{P}(\Theta)}{\sup}\{tm\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)-\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)]-kl(\rho||\pi)\}-\frac{mt^{2}C^{2}}{8}}\right]\leq 1.

Using Lemma 6 with its a=1𝑎1a=1, fix s>0𝑠0s>0 and ρ∈𝒫​(Θ)𝜌𝒫Θ\rho\in\mathcal{P}(\Theta),

𝐏𝐫[supρ∼𝒫​(Θ){tm𝔼θ∼ρ[𝐑𝔻(h)−𝐑𝔻^(h)]−kl(ρ||π)}−m​t2​C28>s]≤𝔼𝒟​[esupρ∼𝒫​(Θ){tm𝔼θ∼ρ[𝐑𝔻(h)−𝐑𝔻^(h)]−kl(ρ||π)}−m​t2​C28]​e−s≤e−s.\begin{split}\mathbf{Pr}&\left[\underset{\rho\sim\mathcal{P}(\Theta)}{\sup}\{tm\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)-\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)]-kl(\rho||\pi)\}-\frac{mt^{2}C^{2}}{8}>s\right]\\ &\leq\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}\left[e^{\underset{\rho\sim\mathcal{P}(\Theta)}{\sup}\{tm\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)-\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)]-kl(\rho||\pi)\}-\frac{mt^{2}C^{2}}{8}}\right]e^{-s}\\ &\leq e^{-s}.\end{split}

So, ∃ρ∈𝒫​(Θ)𝜌𝒫Θ\exists\rho\in\mathcal{P}(\Theta), let ϵ=e−sitalic-ϵsuperscript𝑒𝑠\epsilon=e^{-s} to get:

𝐏𝐫​[𝔼θ∼ρ​[𝐑𝔻​(h)]>𝔼θ∼ρ​[𝐑𝔻^​(h)]+kl(ρ||π)−logϵt​m+t​C28]≤ϵ.\mathbf{Pr}\left[\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)]>\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)]+\frac{kl(\rho||\pi)-\log\epsilon}{tm}+\frac{tC^{2}}{8}\right]\leq\epsilon.

Thus, with probability at least 1−ϵ1italic-ϵ1-\epsilon, for ∀ρ∈𝒫​(Θ)for-all𝜌𝒫Θ\forall\rho\in\mathcal{P}(\Theta) and any hypothesis hℎh with parameter θ𝜃\theta,

𝔼θ∼ρ​[𝐑𝔻​(h)]≤𝔼θ∼ρ​[𝐑𝔻^​(h)]+kl(ρ||π)−logϵt​m+t​C28.\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)]\leq\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\rho}[\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)]+\frac{kl(\rho||\pi)-\log\epsilon}{tm}+\frac{tC^{2}}{8}.

∎

Then, we consider the specific probability ρ𝜌\rho in the set of 𝒫​(Θ)𝒫Θ\mathcal{P}(\Theta) according to [2],

∀θ∈Θ,𝐑𝔻​(h)≤𝐑𝔻^​(h)+−log⁡π−log⁡ϵt​m+t​C28.formulae-sequencefor-all𝜃Θsubscript𝐑𝔻ℎsubscript𝐑^𝔻ℎ𝜋italic-ϵ𝑡𝑚𝑡superscript𝐶28\forall\theta\in\Theta,\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)\leq\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h)+\frac{-{\log\pi}-\log\epsilon}{tm}+\frac{tC^{2}}{8}. (30)

A.2.3 Bound with logit distillation loss

After integrating the generalization error bound with the local risk, we further extend it to logit distillation loss. Fix the prior probability π𝜋\pi of Eq. (30) and apply Definition 4, it gives:

𝐑𝔻​(h)≤1m​∑i=1mℓ​(h​(xi),yi)+λ−log⁡ϵt​m+t​C28,subscript𝐑𝔻ℎ1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚ℓℎsuperscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖𝜆italic-ϵ𝑡𝑚𝑡superscript𝐶28\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}}(h)\leq\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\ell(h(x^{i}),y^{i})+\frac{\lambda-\log\epsilon}{tm}+\frac{tC^{2}}{8}, (31)

which λ=−log⁡π𝜆𝜋\lambda={-\log\pi}. Notably, the above analysis are based on the independent variables. In FedHPL, the private samples among clients is independent in the IID and Non-IID data settings. In Dir data setting, all local data are independent while not necessarily independent across clients. However, the above analysis only needs variables in 𝐑𝔻^​(h)subscript𝐑^𝔻ℎ\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}(h) to be independent, that is to require samples in the local dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} are independent. So, the bound holds in all settings of FedHPL. At the same time, the knowledge among clients is transmitted in the form of logits which are different even using the same image as the input because of different model parameters.

Now, we consider the generalization error over the KD loss ℓk​dsuperscriptℓ𝑘𝑑\ell^{kd} for client k𝑘k in Eq. (2). ℓℓ\ell can be seen as the KD loss with its bound Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} and mensurability. Since clients only upload the correctly predicted logits, the weighted global client-specific logits for each class can be seen as the label space 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}. For representing the global logits with hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}, we integrate the global per-class logit for client k𝑘k with local models and a weighted knowledge aggregation mechanism, then denoted as:

p~k,c=∑j=1Kβ~k,j​∑i=1|𝒟~j,c|pj,ci=∑j=1Kβ~k,j​∑i=1|𝒟~j,c|hj​(xj,ci),subscript~𝑝𝑘𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript~𝒟𝑗𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript~𝒟𝑗𝑐subscriptℎ𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑐𝑖\tilde{p}_{k,c}=\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}_{j,c}|}p_{j,c}^{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}_{j,c}|}h_{j}(x_{j,c}^{i}), (32)

for all client j∈{1,⋯,K}𝑗1⋯𝐾j\in\{1,\cdots,K\}, where h​(xj,ci)ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑐𝑖h(x_{j,c}^{i}) represent the logit of label c𝑐c in client j𝑗j. Specially, we use hj​(Xj,c)subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗𝑐h_{j}(X_{j,c}) to replace ∑i=1|𝒟~j,c|hj​(xj,ci)superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript~𝒟𝑗𝑐subscriptℎ𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑐𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}_{j,c}|}h_{j}(x_{j,c}^{i}) for writing conciseness.

Then, we turn our attention to the loss function ℓℓ\ell over KD loss. With the definition of cross-entropy loss ℓc​e​(p,q)=−∑c′=1ncpc′​log⁡qc′superscriptℓ𝑐𝑒𝑝𝑞superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑐′1subscript𝑛𝑐subscript𝑝superscript𝑐′subscript𝑞superscript𝑐′\ell^{ce}(p,q)=-\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{n_{c}}p_{c^{\prime}}\log q_{c^{\prime}}, information entropy I​(p)=−∑c′=1ncpc′​log⁡pc′𝐼𝑝superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑐′1subscript𝑛𝑐subscript𝑝superscript𝑐′subscript𝑝superscript𝑐′I(p)=-\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{n_{c}}p_{c^{\prime}}\log p_{c^{\prime}}, and KL(p||q)=∑c′=1ncpc′logpc′qc′KL(p||q)=\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{n_{c}}p_{c^{\prime}}\log\frac{p_{c^{\prime}}}{q_{c^{\prime}}}, client k𝑘k computes the distillation distance (i.e. KD loss ℓk​dsuperscriptℓ𝑘𝑑\ell^{kd}) for each local sample xkisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖x_{k}^{i} with its local model hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} (i.e. a backbone Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} with a classification model Hksubscript𝐻𝑘H_{k} and trainable prompts 𝖯ksubscript𝖯𝑘\mathsf{P}_{k}) by:

ℓk​d(p||q)=KL(ϕ𝒯(∑j=1Kβ~k,jhj(Xj,c))||ϕ𝒯(hk(xki)))=∑c′=1nc[ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,c))c′​log⁡ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,c))c′ϕ𝒯​(hk​(xki))c′]=∑c′=1nc[ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,c))c′​log⁡(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,c))c′)]−∑c′=1nc[ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,c))c′​log⁡(ϕ𝒯​(hk​(xki))c′)]=ℓc​e​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,c)),ϕ𝒯​(hk​(xki)))−I​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,c))).\begin{split}\ell^{kd}(p||q)&=KL(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,c}))||\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(x_{k}^{i})))\\ &=\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{n_{c}}\left[\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,c}))_{c^{\prime}}\log\frac{\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,c}))_{c^{\prime}}}{\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(x_{k}^{i}))_{c^{\prime}}}\right]\\ &=\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{n_{c}}\left[\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,c}))_{c^{\prime}}\log(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,c}))_{c^{\prime}})\right]\\ &-\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{n_{c}}\left[\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,c}))_{c^{\prime}}\log(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(x_{k}^{i}))_{c^{\prime}})\right]\\ &=\ell^{ce}(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,c})),\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(x_{k}^{i})))-I(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,c}))).\end{split} (33)

Notably, c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime} is the c-th component value in the local logit pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i} or global logit, whereas c𝑐c represents the category of image xkisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖x_{k}^{i} (i.e. c=yki𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖c=y_{k}^{i}) and ncsubscript𝑛𝑐n_{c} is the number of labels.

Moreover, we use Lemma 7 with the global logits for client k𝑘k to further analyze the error bound:

𝐏𝐫𝔻^​(𝟏​[a​r​g​maxc′⁡hk​(xki)c′≠yki])subscript𝐏𝐫^𝔻1delimited-[]𝑎𝑟𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝑐′subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscript𝑐′superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{Pr}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}\left(\mathbf{1}\left[arg\max_{c^{\prime}}h_{k}(x_{k}^{i})_{c^{\prime}}\neq y_{k}^{i}\right]\right) ≤2−2​𝔼𝔻^​[ϕ𝒯​(hk​(xki))yki]absent22subscript𝔼^𝔻delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝒯subscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\leq 2-2\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{\hat{D}}}\left[\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(x_{k}^{i}))_{y_{k}^{i}}\right] (34)

Remark 3.

Eq. (33) indicates the additional information entropy that we have to transfer knowledge from p𝑝p (i.e. global distribution) to q𝑞q (i.e. local distribution), and Eq. (34) shows that the model performance is related to global logits and the distribution similarity. At the beginning of every global epoch, I​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,yki)))𝐼subscriptitalic-ϕ𝒯superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖I(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,{y_{k}^{i}}}))) is fixed because of the already uploaded local logits to the central server and fixed weight factor β~k,jsubscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}. The more similar the distribution of ∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,yki)superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,{y_{k}^{i}}}) and hk​(xki)ykisubscriptℎ𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖h_{k}(x_{k}^{i})_{y_{k}^{i}} are, the less additional information is required, further reducing the generalization error. Moreover, if global aggregated logits become more precise, the probability of wrong prediction will decrease and further better guide local learning. We also can adjust the local distribution closer to the global distribution by modifying the weight coefficient β~k,jsubscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗\tilde{\beta}_{k,j} and uploading correctly predicted logits to the server to improve the aggregation performance.

Finally, for any ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1), with the probability at least 1−ϵ1italic-ϵ1-\epsilon, we denote 𝐑𝔻​(h)subscript𝐑𝔻ℎ\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{{D}}}(h) in Eq. (31) as 𝐑𝔻kk​d​(hk)superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑘𝑑subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{{D}}_{k}}^{kd}(h_{k}) for client k𝑘k. Exploiting Eq. (32) with the number of local samples |𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘|\mathcal{D}_{k}| and Eq. (33) to Eq. (31) for client k𝑘k, the client-specific generalization error bound over global logit distillation is:

𝐑𝔻kk​d(hk)≤1|𝒟k|∑i=1|𝒟k|KL(ϕ𝒯(∑j=1Kβ~k,jhj(Xj,yki))||ϕ𝒯(hk(xki)))+λk−log⁡ϵt​|𝒟k|+t​Ck28=1|𝒟k|​∑i=1|𝒟k|[ℓc​e​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,yki)),ϕ𝒯​(hk​(xki)))−I​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj,yki)))]+λk−log⁡ϵt​|𝒟k|+t​Ck28,\begin{split}&\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{kd}(h_{k})\leq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}KL(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,{y_{k}^{i}}}))||\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(x_{k}^{i})))+\frac{\lambda_{k}-\log\epsilon}{t|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}+\frac{tC_{k}^{2}}{8}\\ &=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}\left[\ell^{ce}(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,{y_{k}^{i}}})),\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(x_{k}^{i})))-I(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j,{y_{k}^{i}}})))\right]\\ &+\frac{\lambda_{k}-\log\epsilon}{t|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}+\frac{tC_{k}^{2}}{8},\end{split} (35)

where we replace m𝑚m and C𝐶C with |𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘|\mathcal{D}_{k}| and Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k}, respectively. The ℓℓ\ell in Eq. (31) is the loss in Eq. (33). Because the local logits have different labels, we use the corresponding label ykisuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖y_{k}^{i} of xkisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖x_{k}^{i} to replace the c𝑐c in hj​(Xj,c)subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗𝑐h_{j}(X_{j,c}) and denoted as hj​(Xj,yki)subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖h_{j}(X_{j,{y_{k}^{i}}}).

Remark 4.

In addition to distillation distance loss, the number of samples and the loss bound also influence the error. The lower the loss bound Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} and the more samples |𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘|\mathcal{D}_{k}| will improve generalization ability. The sum of weight coefficients β~k,jsubscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗\tilde{\beta}_{k,j} is not required to equal 1. We can control β~k,jsubscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗\tilde{\beta}_{k,j} to modify the global weighted logits and thus influence the distillation loss, further adjusting the error bound and improve the model performance.

For simplification, we use ∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj)superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘𝑗subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j}) and hk​(Xk)subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘h_{k}(X_{k}) to represent all samples, and the generalization error bound over global logit distillation is denoted as:

𝐑𝔻kk​d​(hk)superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑘𝑑subscriptℎ𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{kd}(h_{k}) ≤ℓc​e(ϕ𝒯(∑j=1Kβ~k,jhj(Xj),ϕ𝒯(hk(Xk)))−I(ϕ𝒯(∑j=1Kβ~k,jhj(Xj)))\displaystyle\leq\ell^{ce}(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j}),\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(X_{k})))-I(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j})))
+λk−log⁡ϵt​|𝒟k|+t​Ck28.subscript𝜆𝑘italic-ϵ𝑡subscript𝒟𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑘28\displaystyle+\frac{\lambda_{k}-\log\epsilon}{t|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}+\frac{tC_{k}^{2}}{8}.

A.3 Generalization bound

Inspired by [35], we have 𝐑𝔻k​(hk)≤sup{𝐑𝔻kc​e​(hk),𝐑𝔻kk​d​(hk)}=𝐑𝔻kc​e​(hk)+𝐑𝔻kk​d​(hk)subscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘supremumsuperscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑐𝑒subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑘𝑑subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑐𝑒subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐑subscript𝔻𝑘𝑘𝑑subscriptℎ𝑘\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}(h_{k})\leq\sup\{\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k}),\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{kd}(h_{k})\}=\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k})+\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{k}}^{kd}(h_{k}) for each client k with its local model hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} and local dataset 𝒟k=(Xk,Yk)subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}=(X_{k},Y_{k}). Thus, it gets:

𝐑𝔻T​(hk)≤𝐑𝔻^kc​e​(hk)+kl(hk||h0)+ln4​|𝒟k|−lnϵ2​|𝒟k|+λ𝔻k,𝔻T​(h0)+d𝒞h​((𝔻k)X,(𝔻T)X)+ℓc​e​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj)),ϕ𝒯​(hk​(Xk)))−I​(ϕ𝒯​(∑j=1Kβ~k,j​hj​(Xj)))+λk−log⁡ϵt​|𝒟k|+t​Ck28,\begin{aligned} &\mathbf{R}_{\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{k})\leq\mathbf{R}_{\hat{\mathbb{D}}_{k}}^{ce}(h_{k})+\sqrt{\frac{kl(h_{k}||h_{0})+\ln\sqrt{4|{\mathcal{D}}_{k}|}-\ln\epsilon}{2|{\mathcal{D}}_{k}|}}+\lambda_{\mathbb{D}_{k},\mathbb{D}_{T}}(h_{0})+d_{\mathcal{C}_{h}}((\mathbb{D}_{k})_{X},(\mathbb{D}_{T})_{X})\\ &+\ell^{ce}(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j})),\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(h_{k}(X_{k})))-I(\phi_{\mathcal{T}}(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\tilde{\beta}_{k,j}h_{j}(X_{j})))+\frac{\lambda_{k}-\log\epsilon}{t|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}+\frac{tC_{k}^{2}}{8},\end{aligned}
